basis: The user explicitly commits to implementing anchors, an if-then plan for busy days, and ultra-simple logging, and asks about adjusting reminders. They express testing this week and reporting back, signaling a high likelihood of taking concrete action tonight.
cognitive_dissonance: The user shows tension between BED-related concerns (logging consistency) and a strong desire to stay flexible and compassionate toward themselves. They balance accountability with self-forgiveness, which can manifest as initial hesitation followed by action.
negative_thought_patterns: Some perfectionism tendencies (all-or-nothing notes about needing to log every day), occasional worry about missing logs, and self-criticism around consistency, though tempered by self-compassion phrases.
emotional_triggers: Evening-related triggers (stress, boredom, fatigue), cravings peaking around 7 PM, and environmental cues (kitchen access, snacks) that can prompt use of planned coping strategies.
effective_reinforcement: Recognition of small progress and consistency to reduce discouragement
coaching_notes: Keep reinforcing small, repeatable actions (anchors, one-line log, quick breath). Encourage flexible logging on busy days (one-line entry if needed) and maintain the 10 PM nudge as optional support. Support the user in labeling triggers and emotions to identify patterns, and schedule brief mid-week check-ins to adjust the plan as needed.
